p: Eschscholzia californica Cham. (Papaveraceae) (California poppy) is a native herb from the west coast of North America, mainly found in California. This species is distributed between latitude 32°and 41° N, in climatic conditions very similar to those recorded in its distribution in Chile [28]. This species is usually found at low elevations (below 2000 m altitude) and thrives in warm temperatures [28]. Naturalized populations are found in Australia, Chile, New Zealand and South Africa, among other countries. Beetles pollinate E. californica in its native range and. If pollinated, the resulting fruit is a long, slender pod that dries and splits, shooting tiny round black seeds in all directions. This species persists in the seed bank during dry season, lying dormant as seed for years in some areas. When enough rain falls seeds rapidly germinate and become reproductive in a matter of a few months [28].
